abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that the project
            has proven that coordination at the central level is
            cumbersome. A multisectoral approach in social development
            interventions yields more significant and durable results.
            However, this approach is complex to manage and requires
            engagement and commitment of all levels of government
            (central and local), sectoral ministries as well as the
            civic society. The project correctly foresaw the need to
            assist the government in establishing a reliable system. The
            effectiveness of the system will depend on the
            government's maintaining its interest in using the data
            and in strengthening data collection processes as well as
            its interest in making the data readily available to users.
            The late execution of the establishment of the PMIS under
            the project is one of the key factors handicapping the
            monitoring of Social Priorities Program/Social Priorities
            Programs (SPP/BAJ). As unemployment and underemployment
            remain the biggest problems confronting the Moroccan
            government, Bank-supported programs/projects should view the
            PN as a potential partner in order not to miss the
            employment-generating opportunities offered by PN
            implementation methods. Even though the legal covenant set
            under the project has a valid objective, i.e. to reorient PN
            activities in favor of activities aiming at reducing
            poverty, it is not realistically feasible without having
            parallel mechanisms to provide income to the category of
            workers associated with the jobs of temporary nature (EOO).
